1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Urethane Polymers International, Inc. (UPI) is very concerned with the safety of its workers and individuals living and working near the facility.  UPI has therefore implemented a number of measures to insure that UPI maintains its safe working environment.  These measure include:
- Detailed and comprehensive Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for all major operations at the facility.  These SOPs include elements to prevent accidents from occurring and response steps to take if accidents do occur.
- Comprehensive training and testing for all employees.  All manufacturing employees must successfully pass written, oral, and demonstration tests prior to their working with hazardous substances and around hazardous equipment.
- Establishment of detailed materials handling procedures.
- Safe-work policies posted for all employees to review on a continual basis. 
- Work safety practices that include requirements for hot work permits, confined space permits, and lockout and tagging of equipment during maintenance.

1.2 General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

1.2.1 Description of Stationary Source

The UPI facility performs custom manufacturing of waterproofing compounds (NAICS code 32551).  The facility is located at 10880 Poplar Avenue, Fontana, California.  Approximately 12 workers will be employed at the UPI facility.  UPI uses toluene diisocyanate (TDI), isophorone diisocyanate (IPDI), and other materials to prepare the waterproofing compounds.  The TDI and IPDI are stored in 55-gallon drums.  

In Fontana, the Administrating Agency (AA) for an RMP and a CalARP plan is the San Bernardino County Fire Department (SBCFD).  

Both the RMP and CalARP programs have defined specific threshold quantities (TQs) for hazardous chemicals covered under the programs.  If a given process uses an amount of the regulated substance greater than the TQ, the regulated substance is subject to

the requirements of the program.  TDI is regulated under RMP and CalARP regulations.  IPDI is only regulated under the CalARP regulations.  For TDI, the RMP TQ is 10,000 pounds and the CalARP TQ is 500 pounds for the 2,4- isomer and 100 pounds for the 2,6- isomer.  The CalARP TQ for IPDI is 100 pounds.  Neither of these chemicals is regulated by the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management Program (PSM).

The UPI facility stores the drums of TDI and IPDI in a segregated storage area.  Both the RMP and CalARP regulations define the storage of separate drums in a common storage area as a single process.  The facility is planning to store up to 80x55-gallon drums of TDI on-site at one time and up to 40x55-gallon drums of IPDI on-site at one time.  Therefore, the maximum inventory consists of approximately 44,000 pounds of TDI and 18,000 pounds of IPDI.  The maximum TDI content at UPI is above the RMP TQ and is also above the CalARP TQ.  The maximum IPDI content at UPI is above the CalARP TQ.  Therefore, UPI is subject to both the California CalARP program and to the Federal RMP program.

The major hazards represented by the process are the release of toxic substances (TDI and IPDI) due to spills and mixing vessel rupture.  Transportation or storage accidents involving these chemicals are the scenarios that would produce the largest spill and potential release of regulated substances. 

1.2.2 Description of the Process

The raw materials are received at the UPI loading dock via trucks in 55-gallon drums.   Up to 72 drums of TDI may be received at one time, and up to 40 drums of IPDI may be received at one time.  The maximum quantity of TDI stored on-site is 80 drums and the maximum quantity of IPDI stored on-site is 40 drums.  

The TDI and IPDI are transferred from the loading dock area via forklift to a dedicated storage room, where they are stored until needed in the reactor room.  At that time, they are transferred by fork

lift to the reactor room.  The material is manually transferred by a slight vacuum into the mix chamber.  When the specified quantity of TDI and/or IPDI has been transferred, the flow is stopped.  The remaining required ingredients (including polyols, colorants, fillers, curing modifiers, and thinners) are added and the product is blended.  After blending is complete, the finished product is removed and placed into containers for storage and future shipment.

1.3 Worst-Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenarios

1.3.1 Worst-Case Scenario

The worst-case scenario analyzed in the Off-site Consequence Analysis (OCA) is a pallet of four (4) drums being dropped while being transported via forklift and the drums rupturing.  The resulting spill is assumed to be unconfined with no passive mitigation measures in place. 

This worst-case scenario is a very unlikely scenario for two reasons.  
- All resin drums are U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) approved drums and are designed to accept significant damage without failing.  
- The OCA assumed conditions of F stability and 1.5 m/s wind speed, the worst-case scenario conditions required by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for an RMP worst-case analysis.  However, stability conditions of F only occur at night but deliveries of these materials normally occur during the day.   

The model computed a TDI emission rate of 0.0074 pounds per minute for this worst-case scenario.  The emission rate for IPDI was estimated to be 0.0037 pounds per minute.  Based on the results from the TSCREEN3 model, the airborne concentration of TDI never reaches the significant impact level (endpoint distance) for the worst-case scenario.  The maximum concentration (2,000 mg/L) occurs at approximately 65 feet.  

Based on the results from the TSCREEN3 model, the airborne concentration of IPDI never reaches the significant impact level (endpoint distance).  The maximum concentration (130 mg/L) occurs at approximately 65 feet.

Since the impact distances for both potential chemicals of concern are on-site there is no off-site impact and the facility is eligible to be a Program 1 facility.  

The facility is expecting to be classified as a Program 1 facility, therefore alternate release scenarios are not required.

1.4 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Individual components of the Accidental Release Prevention Program at the UPI facility include the following:
- Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been created for all major operations at the facility.  These SOPs include elements to prevent accidents from occurring and response steps to take if accidents do occur.
- Comprehensive training and testing is required for employees.  All manufacturing employees must successfully pass written, oral, and demonstration tests prior to their working with hazardous substances and around hazardous equipment.
- Detailed materials handling procedures are in-place for all resins, including those containing formaldehydes and phenols.
- Safe-work policies have been created and are available for all employees to review on a continual basis. 
- Work safety practices that have been implemented include requirements for hot work permits, confined space permits, line breaking permits, and lockout and tagging of equipment during maintenance.

1.5 Five Year Accident History

The facility is a new facility so there is no accident history.

1.6 The Emergency Response Program

When spills occur, an emergency response plan is in place to detail with the spill, to identify why the spill happened, and to implement measures to prevent future spills of the same and similar type from happening.  The emergency response plan has been submitted to the San Bernardino County Fire Department (SBCFD).
- Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been created for all major operations at the facility.  These SOPs detail the response steps to take if upset conditions do occur.

- The local emergency response agencies (SBCFD, local police department) have been contacted to communicate the potential hazards at the facility and the expected response measures that will be taken in the event of an emergency.
- Comprehensive training and testing is required for employees.  All manufacturing employees must successfully pass written, oral, and demonstration tests prior to their working with hazardous substances and around hazardous equipment.
- Detailed materials handling procedures are in-place for all materials, including TDI and IPDI.
- Creation and deployment of spill kits throughout the work area to allow rapid containment and minimization of area affected by the spill.

1.7 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility is a new facility so there are no planned changes at this time to improve safety.  However, the facility operations will be reviewed if the emergency response program is activated to determine if there are operational procedures or physical improvements that can be made to improve safety at the facility.
